A message from Brandon Schools Food Service Department:

On August 31, 2020, the United States Department of Agricultural (USDA) announced they are allowing school nutrition programs to continue feeding children during the pandemic. This means that ALL children 18 years of age and younger will be provided breakfast and lunch at no cost to families. This includes face to face and at home learners. Brandon Learn from Home or Summit Virtual families can pick up food every week by filling out the pre order form that is on the district website or the link below. Currently the waiver allows us to provide this service through December 2020, or until federal funding is depleted.

Please contact Monica Genslak, Food Service Director at mgenslak@brandon.k12.mi.us or 248-627-1828 with any questions.

Brandon Learn from Home is now open for enrollment!
Brandon Learn from Home creates a connection between children JK-12, their parents, teachers and the school through a shared partnership remote learning experience. All Brandon Learn from Home courses are taught by Brandon teachers and the curriculum is identical to the curriculum at all levels within the Brandon School District. While some elective course offerings may be unique, the core grade level and graduation requirements of both the State of Michigan and the Brandon School District are identical. At Brandon Learn from Home we believe all means all and we will ensure that ALL students receive the knowledge, skills, and highest quality education to soar above the rest!

Visit www.BrandonLearnFromHome.com to learn more and to register for Fall 2020.

Questions? Please email Mr. Wyatt at dwyatt@brandon.k12.mi.us

Congratulations to this years winner of the Brandon School District Secondary Teacher of the Year Award:

Laura Frye has served the Brandon School District for nearly three decades as a special education teacher and much more. Over the past several years, Mrs. Frye has led the adult transition program which is a program that assists adult special education students with independent living. In this role, Mrs. Frye has brought so many opportunities to her students and has made a long-lasting impact on their lives and those of their families. She is positive, student focused, incredibly creative and a passionate advocate for each of her students. We are fortunate to have such an outstanding educator in our district and it is a great honor to recognize her incredible impact on others.

Students in Mrs. Morales's class loved coding last week during PLTW!

The Hour of Code started as a one-hour introduction to computer science, designed to demystify "code", to show that anybody can learn the basics, and to broaden participation in the field of computer science. It has since become a worldwide effort to celebrate computer science, starting with 1-hour coding activities but expanding to all sorts of community efforts. 100 million students have now discovered how accessible and fun computer science can be by doing just one Hour of Code.
